question_text: Which of the following is a purpose of the Amateur Radio Service as stated in the FCC rules and regulations?
answer_lines: A. Providing personal radio communications for as many citizens as possible
B. Providing communications for international non-profit organizations
C. Advancing skills in the technical and communication phases of the radio art
D. All of these choices are correct
correct_answers: C. Advancing skills in the technical and communication phases of the radio art

question_text: Which agency regulates and enforces the rules for the Amateur Radio Service in the United States?
correct_answers: C. The FCC

question_text: Which part of the FCC regulations contains the rules governing the Amateur Radio Service?
correct_answers: D. Part 97

question_text: Which of the following meets the FCC definition of harmful interference?
answer_lines: A. Radio transmissions that annoy users of a repeater
B. Unwanted radio transmissions that cause costly harm to radio station apparatus
C. That which seriously degrades, obstructs, or repeatedly interrupts a radio communication service operating in accordance with the Radio Regulations
correct_answers: C. That which seriously degrades, obstructs, or repeatedly interrupts a radio communication service operating in accordance with the Radio Regulations

question_text: Which of the following is a purpose of the Amateur Radio Service rules and regulations as defined by the FCC?
answer_lines: B. Providing inexpensive communication for local emergency organizations
C. Training of operators in military radio operating procedures
D. All of these choices are correct
correct_answers: A. Enhancing international goodwill

question_text: Which of the following services are protected from interference by amateur signals under all circumstances?
correct_answers: D. Radionavigation Service

question_text: What is the FCC Part 97 definition of telemetry?
answer_lines: A. An information bulletin issued by the FCC
B. A one-way transmission to initiate, modify or terminate functions of a device at a distance
C. A one-way transmission of measurements at a distance from the measuring instrument
D. An information bulletin from a VEC
correct_answers: C. A one-way transmission of measurements at a distance from the measuring instrument

question_text: Which of the following entities recommends transmit/receive channels and other parameters for auxiliary and repeater stations?
correct_answers: B. Frequency Coordinator

question_text: Who selects a Frequency Coordinator?
answer_lines: A. The FCC Office of Spectrum Management and Coordination Policy
B. The local chapter of the Office of National Council of Independent Frequency Coordinators
C. Amateur operators in a local or regional area whose stations are eligible to be auxiliary or repeater stations
correct_answers: C. Amateur operators in a local or regional area whose stations are eligible to be auxiliary or repeater stations

question_text: What is the FCC Part 97 definition of an amateur station?
answer_lines: A. A station in the Amateur Radio Service consisting of the apparatus necessary for carrying on radio communications
B. A building where Amateur Radio receivers, transmitters, and RF power amplifiers are installed
C. Any radio station operated by a non-professional
D. Any radio station for hobby use
correct_answers: A. A station in the Amateur Radio Service consisting of the apparatus necessary for carrying on radio communications

question_text: When is willful interference to other amateur radio stations permitted?
answer_lines: A. Only if the station being interfered with is expressing extreme religious or political views
D. At any time, amateurs are not protected from willful interference
correct_answers: B. At no time

question_text: Which of the following is a permissible use of the Amateur Radio Service?
answer_lines: A. Broadcasting music and videos to friends
B. Providing a way for amateur radio operators to earn additional income by using their stations to pass messages
C. Providing low-cost communications for start-up businesses
D. Allowing a person to conduct radio experiments and to communicate with other licensed hams around the world
correct_answers: D. Allowing a person to conduct radio experiments and to communicate with other licensed hams around the world

question_text: What is the FCC Part 97 definition of telecommand?
answer_lines: A. An instruction bulletin issued by the FCC
B. A one-way radio transmission of measurements at a distance from the measuring instrument
C. A one-way transmission to initiate, modify or terminate functions of a device at a distance
D. An instruction from a VEC
correct_answers: C. A one-way transmission to initiate, modify or terminate functions of a device at a distance

question_text: What must you do if you are operating on the 23 cm band and learn that you are interfering with a radiolocation station outside the United States?
answer_lines: A. Stop operating or take steps to eliminate the harmful interference
B. Nothing, because this band is allocated exclusively to the amateur service
C. Establish contact with the radiolocation station and ask them to change frequency
D. Change to CW mode, because this would not likely cause interference
correct_answers: A. Stop operating or take steps to eliminate the harmful interference

question_text: What is the ITU?
answer_lines: A. An agency of the United States Department of Telecommunications Management
B. A United Nations agency for information and communication technology issues
C. An independent frequency coordination agency
D. A department of the FCC
correct_answers: B. A United Nations agency for information and communication technology issues

question_text: Why are the frequency assignments for some U.S. Territories different from those in the 50 U.S. States?
answer_lines: A. Some U. S. Territories are located in ITU regions other than region 2
B. Territorial governments are allowed to select their own frequency allocations
C. Territorial frequency allocations must also include those of adjacent countries
D. Any territory that was in existence before the ratification of the Communications Act of 1934 is exempt from FCC frequency regulations
correct_answers: A. Some U. S. Territories are located in ITU regions other than region 2

question_text: Which frequency is within the 6 meter band?
Which amateur band are you using when your station is transmitting on 146.52 MHz?
correct_answers: A. 2 meter band

question_text: Which 70 cm frequency is authorized to a Technician Class license holder operating in ITU Region 2?
Which 23 cm frequency is authorized to a Technician Class licensee?
correct_answers: B. 1296 MHz

question_text: What amateur band are you using if you are transmitting on 223.50 MHz?
correct_answers: D. 1.25 meter band

question_text: Which of the following is a result of the fact that the amateur service is secondary in some portions of the 70 cm band?
answer_lines: A. U.S. amateurs may find non-amateur stations in the bands, and must avoid interfering with them
B. U.S. amateurs must give foreign amateur stations priority in those portions
C. International communications are not permitted on 70 cm
D. Digital transmissions are not permitted on 70 cm
correct_answers: A. U.S. amateurs may find non-amateur stations in the bands, and must avoid interfering with them

question_text: Why should you not set your transmit frequency to be exactly at the edge of an amateur band or sub-band?
answer_lines: A. To allow for calibration error in the transmitter frequency display
B. So that modulation sidebands do not extend beyond the band edge
C. To allow for transmitter frequency drift
D. All of these choices are correct
correct_answers: A. To allow for calibration error in the transmitter frequency display
B. So that modulation sidebands do not extend beyond the band edge
C. To allow for transmitter frequency drift

question_text: Which of the bands above 30 MHz that are available to Technician Class operators have mode-restricted sub-bands?
answer_lines: A. The 6 meter, 2 meter, and 70 cm bands
B. The 2 meter and 13 cm bands
C. The 6 meter, 2 meter, and 1.25 meter bands
D. The 2 meter and 70 cm bands
correct_answers: C. The 6 meter, 2 meter, and 1.25 meter bands

question_text: What emission modes are permitted in the mode-restricted sub-bands at 50.0 to 50.1 MHz and 144.0 to 144.1 MHz?
correct_answers: A. CW only

question_text: Why are frequency assignments for U.S. stations operating maritime mobile not the same everywhere in the world?
answer_lines: A. Amateur maritime mobile stations in international waters must conform to the frequency assignments of the country nearest to their vessel
B. Amateur frequency assignments can vary among the three ITU regions
C. Frequency assignments are determined by the captain of the vessel
D. Amateur frequency assignments are different in each of the 90 ITU zones
correct_answers: B. Amateur frequency assignments can vary among the three ITU regions

question_text: Which emission may be used between 219 and 220 MHz?
correct_answers: B. Data

question_text: Which type of call sign has a single letter in both its prefix and suffix?
correct_answers: C. Special event

question_text: Which of the following is a valid US amateur radio station call sign?
correct_answers: B. W3ABC

question_text: What types of international communications are permitted by an FCC-licensed amateur station?
answer_lines: A. Communications incidental to the purposes of the amateur service and remarks of a personal character
B. Communications incidental to conducting business or remarks of a personal nature
C. Only communications incidental to contest exchanges, all other communications are prohibited
D. Any communications that would be permitted by an international broadcast station
correct_answers: A. Communications incidental to the purposes of the amateur service and remarks of a personal character

question_text: When are you allowed to operate your amateur station in a foreign country?
answer_lines: A. When the foreign country authorizes it
B. When there is a mutual agreement allowing third party communications
C. When authorization permits amateur communications in a foreign language
D. When you are communicating with non-licensed individuals in another country
correct_answers: A. When the foreign country authorizes it

question_text: Which of the following is a vanity call sign which a technician class amateur operator might select if available?
answer_lines: D. All of these choices are correct
correct_answers: A. K1XXX

question_text: From which of the following locations may an FCC-licensed amateur station transmit, in addition to places where the FCC regulates communications?
answer_lines: A. From within any country that belongs to the International Telecommunications Union
B. From within any country that is a member of the United Nations
C. From anywhere within in ITU Regions 2 and 3
D. From any vessel or craft located in international waters and documented or registered in the United States
correct_answers: D. From any vessel or craft located in international waters and documented or registered in the United States

question_text: What may result when correspondence from the FCC is returned as undeliverable because the grantee failed to provide the correct mailing address?
answer_lines: B. Revocation of the station license or suspension of the operator license
C. Require the licensee to be re-examined
D. A reduction of one rank in operator class
correct_answers: B. Revocation of the station license or suspension of the operator license

question_text: What is the normal term for an FCC-issued primary station/operator amateur radio license grant?
correct_answers: C. Ten years

question_text: What is the grace period following the expiration of an amateur license within which the license may be renewed?
correct_answers: A. Two years

question_text: How soon after passing the examination for your first amateur radio license may you operate a transmitter on an amateur service frequency?
answer_lines: B. 30 days after the test date
C. As soon as your operator/station license grant appears in the FCC’s license database
D. You must wait until you receive your license in the mail from the FCC
correct_answers: C. As soon as your operator/station license grant appears in the FCC’s license database

question_text: If your license has expired and is still within the allowable grace period, may you continue to operate a transmitter on amateur service frequencies?
answer_lines: A. No, transmitting is not allowed until the FCC license database shows that the license has been renewed
B. Yes, but only if you identify using the suffix GP
C. Yes, but only during authorized nets
D. Yes, for up to two years
correct_answers: A. No, transmitting is not allowed until the FCC license database shows that the license has been renewed

question_text: Who may select a desired call sign under the vanity call sign rules?
answer_lines: A. Only licensed amateurs with general or extra class licenses
B. Only licensed amateurs with an extra class license
C. Only an amateur licensee who has been licensed continuously for more than 10 years
correct_answers: D. Any licensed amateur

question_text: For which licenses classes are new licenses currently available from the FCC?
answer_lines: B. Technician, Technician Plus, General, Advanced
C. Novice, Technician Plus, General, Advanced
correct_answers: D. Technician, General, Amateur Extra

question_text: Who may select a vanity call sign for a club station?
answer_lines: A. Any Extra Class member of the club
B. Any member of the club
C. Any officer of the club
D. Only the person named as trustee on the club station license grant
correct_answers: D. Only the person named as trustee on the club station license grant

question_text: With which countries are FCC-licensed amateur stations prohibited from exchanging communications?
answer_lines: A. Any country whose administration has notified the ITU that it objects to such communications
B. Any country whose administration has notified the ARRL that it objects to such communications
C. Any country engaged in hostilities with another country
D. Any country in violation of the War Powers Act of 1934
correct_answers: A. Any country whose administration has notified the ITU that it objects to such communications

question_text: On which of the following occasions may an FCC-licensed amateur station exchange messages with a U.S. military station?
answer_lines: A. During an Armed Forces Day Communications Test
B. During a Memorial Day Celebration
C. During an Independence Day celebration
correct_answers: A. During an Armed Forces Day Communications Test

question_text: When is the transmission of codes or ciphers that hide the meaning of a message allowed by an amateur station?
answer_lines: C. Only when transmitting control commands to space stations or radio control craft
D. Only when frequencies above 1280 MHz are used
correct_answers: C. Only when transmitting control commands to space stations or radio control craft

question_text: What is the only time an amateur station is authorized to transmit music?
answer_lines: A. When incidental to an authorized retransmission of manned spacecraft communications
B. When the music produces no spurious emissions
C. When the purpose is to interfere with an illegal transmission
D. When the music is transmitted above 1280 MHz
correct_answers: A. When incidental to an authorized retransmission of manned spacecraft communications

question_text: When may amateur radio operators use their stations to notify other amateurs of the availability of equipment for sale or trade?
answer_lines: A. When the equipment is normally used in an amateur station and such activity is not conducted on a regular basis
B. When the asking price is $100.00 or less
C. When the asking price is less than its appraised value
D. When the equipment is not the personal property of either the station licensee or the control operator or their close relatives
correct_answers: A. When the equipment is normally used in an amateur station and such activity is not conducted on a regular basis

question_text: What, if any, are the restrictions concerning transmission of language that may be considered indecent or obscene?
answer_lines: A. The FCC maintains a list of words that are not permitted to be used on amateur frequencies
B. Any such language is prohibited
C. The ITU maintains a list of words that are not permitted to be used on amateur frequencies
D. There is no such prohibition
correct_answers: B. Any such language is prohibited

question_text: What types of amateur stations can automatically retransmit the signals of other amateur stations?
answer_lines: A. Auxiliary, beacon, or Earth stations
B. Auxiliary, repeater, or space stations
C. Beacon, repeater, or space stations
D. Earth, repeater, or space stations
correct_answers: B. Auxiliary, repeater, or space stations

question_text: In which of the following circumstances may the control operator of an amateur station receive compensation for operating the station?
answer_lines: A. When engaging in communications on behalf of their employer
B. When the communication is incidental to classroom instruction at an educational institution
C. When re-broadcasting weather alerts during a RACES net
D. When notifying other amateur operators of the availability for sale or trade of apparatus
correct_answers: B. When the communication is incidental to classroom instruction at an educational institution

question_text: Under which of the following circumstances are amateur stations authorized to transmit signals related to broadcasting, program production, or news gathering, assuming no other means is available?
answer_lines: A. Only where such communications directly relate to the immediate safety of human life or protection of property
B. Only when broadcasting communications to or from the space shuttle
C. Only where noncommercial programming is gathered and supplied exclusively to the National Public Radio network
D. Only when using amateur repeaters linked to the Internet
correct_answers: A. Only where such communications directly relate to the immediate safety of human life or protection of property

question_text: What is the meaning of the term “broadcasting” in the FCC rules for the amateur services?
answer_lines: A. Two-way transmissions by amateur stations
C. Transmission of messages directed only to amateur operators
D. Transmissions intended for reception by the general public
correct_answers: D. Transmissions intended for reception by the general public

question_text: When may an amateur station transmit without identifying?
answer_lines: A. When the transmissions are of a brief nature to make station adjustments
B. When the transmissions are unmodulated
C. When the transmitted power level is below 1 watt
D. When transmitting signals to control a model craft
correct_answers: D. When transmitting signals to control a model craft

question_text: Under which of the following circumstances may an amateur radio station engage in broadcasting?
answer_lines: B. When transmitting code practice, information bulletins, or transmissions necessary to provide emergency communications
C. At any time as long as no music is transmitted
D. At any time as long as the material being transmitted did not originate from a commercial broadcast station
correct_answers: B. When transmitting code practice, information bulletins, or transmissions necessary to provide emergency communications

question_text: When is an amateur station permitted to transmit without a control operator?
answer_lines: A. When using automatic control, such as in the case of a repeater
B. When the station licensee is away and another licensed amateur is using the station
C. When the transmitting station is an auxiliary station
correct_answers: D. Never

question_text: Who may a station licensee designate to be the control operator of an amateur station?
answer_lines: A. Any U.S. citizen or registered alien
B. Any family member of the station licensee
C. Any person over the age of 18
D. Only a person for whom an amateur operator/primary station license grant appears in the FCC database or who is authorized for alien reciprocal operation
correct_answers: D. Only a person for whom an amateur operator/primary station license grant appears in the FCC database or who is authorized for alien reciprocal operation

question_text: Who must designate the station control operator?
correct_answers: A. The station licensee

question_text: What determines the transmitting privileges of an amateur station?
answer_lines: A. The frequency authorized by the frequency coordinator
B. The class of operator license held by the station licensee
C. The highest class of operator license held by anyone on the premises
D. The class of operator license held by the control operator
correct_answers: D. The class of operator license held by the control operator

question_text: What is an amateur station control point?
answer_lines: A. The location of the station’s transmitting antenna
B. The location of the station transmitting apparatus
C. The location at which the control operator function is performed
D. The mailing address of the station licensee
correct_answers: C. The location at which the control operator function is performed

question_text: Under what type of control do APRS network digipeaters operate?
correct_answers: A. Automatic

question_text: When the control operator is not the station licensee, who is responsible for the proper operation of the station?
answer_lines: A. All licensed amateurs who are present at the operation
D. The control operator and the station licensee are equally responsible
correct_answers: D. The control operator and the station licensee are equally responsible

question_text: Which of the following is an example of automatic control?
answer_lines: B. Controlling the station over the Internet
C. Using a computer or other device to automatically send CW
D. Using a computer or other device to automatically identify
correct_answers: A. Repeater operation

question_text: What type of control is being used when the control operator is at the control point?
correct_answers: D. Local control

question_text: Which of the following is an example of remote control as defined in Part 97?
answer_lines: B. Operating the station over the Internet
C. Controlling a model aircraft, boat or car by amateur radio
D. All of these choices are correct
correct_answers: B. Operating the station over the Internet

question_text: Who does the FCC presume to be the control operator of an amateur station, unless documentation to the contrary is in the station records?
answer_lines: C. The person operating the station equipment
correct_answers: D. The station licensee

question_text: When, under normal circumstances, may a Technician Class licensee be the control operator of a station operating in an exclusive Extra Class operator segment of the amateur bands?
answer_lines: B. When operating a special event station
C. As part of a multi-operator contest team
D. When using a club station whose trustee is an Extra Class operator licensee
correct_answers: A. At no time

question_text: What type of identification is being used when identifying a station on the air as Race Headquarters?
answer_lines: B. An official call sign reserved for RACES drills
correct_answers: A. Tactical call sign

question_text: When using tactical identifiers such as “Race Headquarters” during a community service net operation, how often must your station transmit the station’s FCC-assigned call sign?
answer_lines: A. Never, the tactical call is sufficient
C. At the end of each communication and every ten minutes during a communication
D. At the end of every transmission
correct_answers: C. At the end of each communication and every ten minutes during a communication

question_text: When is an amateur station required to transmit its assigned call sign?
answer_lines: A. At the beginning of each contact, and every 10 minutes thereafter
B. At least once during each transmission
C. At least every 15 minutes during and at the end of a communication
D. At least every 10 minutes during and at the end of a communication
correct_answers: D. At least every 10 minutes during and at the end of a communication

question_text: Which of the following is an acceptable language to use for station identification when operating in a phone sub-band?
answer_lines: A. Any language recognized by the United Nations
B. Any language recognized by the ITU
correct_answers: C. The English language

question_text: What method of call sign identification is required for a station transmitting phone signals?
answer_lines: A. Send the call sign followed by the indicator RPT
B. Send the call sign using CW or phone emission
C. Send the call sign followed by the indicator R
D. Send the call sign using only phone emission
correct_answers: B. Send the call sign using CW or phone emission

question_text: Which of the following formats of a self-assigned indicator is acceptable when identifying using a phone transmission?
answer_lines: D. All of these choices are correct
correct_answers: A. KL7CC stroke W3
B. KL7CC slant W3
C. KL7CC slash W3

question_text: Which of the following restrictions apply when a non-licensed person is allowed to speak to a foreign station using a station under the control of a Technician Class control operator?
answer_lines: A. The person must be a U.S. citizen
B. The foreign station must be one with which the U.S. has a third party agreement
C. The licensed control operator must do the station identification
D. All of these choices are correct
correct_answers: B. The foreign station must be one with which the U.S. has a third party agreement

question_text: Which indicator is required by the FCC to be transmitted after a station call sign?
answer_lines: C. / followed the FCC Region number when operating out of the region in which the license was issued
D. /KT, /AE or /AG when using new license privileges earned by CSCE while waiting for an upgrade to a previously issued license to appear in the FCC license database
correct_answers: D. /KT, /AE or /AG when using new license privileges earned by CSCE while waiting for an upgrade to a previously issued license to appear in the FCC license database

question_text: What type of amateur station simultaneously retransmits the signal of another amateur station on a different channel or channels?
correct_answers: C. Repeater station

question_text: Who is accountable should a repeater inadvertently retransmit communications that violate the FCC rules?
answer_lines: A. The control operator of the originating station
B. The control operator of the repeater
C. The owner of the repeater
D. Both the originating station and the repeater owner
correct_answers: A. The control operator of the originating station

question_text: To which foreign stations do the FCC rules authorize the transmission of non-emergency third party communications?
answer_lines: A. Any station whose government permits such communications
B. Those in ITU Region 2 only
C. Those in ITU Regions 2 and 3 only
D. Those in ITU Region 3 only
correct_answers: A. Any station whose government permits such communications

question_text: How many persons are required to be members of a club for a club station license to be issued by the FCC?
correct_answers: B. At least 4

question_text: When must the station licensee make the station and its records available for FCC inspection?
answer_lines: A. At any time ten days after notification by the FCC of such an inspection
B. At any time upon request by an FCC representative
C. Only after failing to comply with an FCC notice of violation
D. Only when presented with a valid warrant by an FCC official or government agent
correct_answers: B. At any time upon request by an FCC representative

question_text: What is the most common repeater frequency offset in the 2 meter band?
correct_answers: B. Plus or minus 600 kHz

question_text: What is the national calling frequency for FM simplex operations in the 70 cm band?
What is a common repeater frequency offset in the 70 cm band?
correct_answers: A. Plus or minus 5 MHz

question_text: What is an appropriate way to call another station on a repeater if you know the other station's call sign?
answer_lines: A. Say break, break then say the station's call sign
B. Say the station's call sign then identify with your call sign
C. Say CQ three times then the other station's call sign
D. Wait for the station to call CQ then answer it
correct_answers: B. Say the station's call sign then identify with your call sign

question_text: How should you respond to a station calling CQ?
answer_lines: A. Transmit CQ followed by the other station’s call sign
B. Transmit your call sign followed by the other station’s call sign
C. Transmit the other station’s call sign followed by your call sign
D. Transmit a signal report followed by your call sign
correct_answers: C. Transmit the other station’s call sign followed by your call sign

question_text: What must an amateur operator do when making on-air transmissions to test equipment or antennas?
answer_lines: A. Properly identify the transmitting station
B. Make test transmissions only after 10:00 p.m. local time
C. Notify the FCC of the test transmission
D. State the purpose of the test during the test procedure
correct_answers: A. Properly identify the transmitting station

question_text: Which of the following is true when making a test transmission?
answer_lines: A. Station identification is not required if the transmission is less than 15 seconds
B. Station identification is not required if the transmission is less than 1 watt
C. Station identification is only required once an hour when the transmissions are for test purposes only
D. Station identification is required at least every ten minutes during the test and at the end of the test
correct_answers: D. Station identification is required at least every ten minutes during the test and at the end of the test

question_text: What is the meaning of the procedural signal “CQ”?
answer_lines: A. Call on the quarter hour
B. A new antenna is being tested (no station should answer)
C. Only the called station should transmit
correct_answers: D. Calling any station

question_text: What brief statement is often transmitted in place of “CQ” to indicate that you are listening on a repeater?
answer_lines: A. The words “Hello test” followed by your call sign
C. The repeater call sign followed by your call sign
D. The letters “QSY” followed by your call sign
correct_answers: B. Your call sign

question_text: What is a band plan, beyond the privileges established by the FCC?
answer_lines: A. A voluntary guideline for using different modes or activities within an amateur band
B. A mandated list of operating schedules
C. A list of scheduled net frequencies
D. A plan devised by a club to indicate frequency band usage
correct_answers: A. A voluntary guideline for using different modes or activities within an amateur band

question_text: Which of the following is an FCC rule regarding power levels used in the amateur bands, under normal, non-distress circumstances?
answer_lines: A. There is no limit to power as long as there is no interference with other services
B. No more than 200 watts PEP may be used
C. Up to 1500 watts PEP may be used on any amateur frequency without restriction
D. While not exceeding the maximum power permitted on a given band, use the minimum power necessary to carry out the desired communication
correct_answers: D. While not exceeding the maximum power permitted on a given band, use the minimum power necessary to carry out the desired communication

question_text: Which of the following is a guideline to use when choosing an operating frequency for calling CQ?
answer_lines: A. Listen first to be sure that no one else is using the frequency
B. Ask if the frequency is in use
C. Make sure you are in your assigned band
D. All of these choices are correct
correct_answers: A. Listen first to be sure that no one else is using the frequency
B. Ask if the frequency is in use
C. Make sure you are in your assigned band

question_text: What is the term used to describe an amateur station that is transmitting and receiving on the same frequency?
correct_answers: C. Simplex communication

question_text: What is the term used to describe the use of a sub-audible tone transmitted with normal voice audio to open the squelch of a receiver?
correct_answers: D. CTCSS

question_text: Which of the following describes the muting of receiver audio controlled solely by the presence or absence of an RF signal?
correct_answers: B. Carrier squelch

question_text: Which of the following common problems might cause you to be able to hear but not access a repeater even when transmitting with the proper offset?
answer_lines: A. The repeater receiver may require an audio tone burst for access
B. The repeater receiver may require a CTCSS tone for access
C. The repeater receiver may require a DCS tone sequence for access
D. All of these choices are correct
correct_answers: A. The repeater receiver may require an audio tone burst for access
B. The repeater receiver may require a CTCSS tone for access
C. The repeater receiver may require a DCS tone sequence for access

question_text: What determines the amount of deviation of an FM (as opposed to PM) signal?
answer_lines: A. Both the frequency and amplitude of the modulating signal
B. The frequency of the modulating signal
C. The amplitude of the modulating signal
D. The relative phase of the modulating signal and the carrier
correct_answers: C. The amplitude of the modulating signal

question_text: What happens when the deviation of an FM transmitter is increased?
answer_lines: A. Its signal occupies more bandwidth
C. Its output power and bandwidth increases
correct_answers: A. Its signal occupies more bandwidth

question_text: What could cause your FM signal to interfere with stations on nearby frequencies?
answer_lines: A. Microphone gain too high, causing over-deviation
D. All of these choices are correct
correct_answers: A. Microphone gain too high, causing over-deviation

question_text: Which of the following applies when two stations transmitting on the same frequency interfere with each other?
answer_lines: A. Common courtesy should prevail, but no one has absolute right to an amateur frequency
B. Whoever has the strongest signal has priority on the frequency
C. Whoever has been on the frequency the longest has priority on the frequency
